channel.title: Question made my brain explode
channel.description:
I am going to throw something out my window cause this is like impossible and makes no sense
One day, a person went to a race track. Instead of counting the number of human and cars, he instead counted 74 heads and 196 tires. Yet he knew the number of humans and horses there. How did he do it, and how many humans and cars are there?
My teacher gave us this for extra credit for 80 points lol and I have asked so many people. Any idea? SOMETHING? or do i need a scientist

item.title: Question made my brain explode
item.dc:creator: @matzie matzie
item.description:
@matzie wrote:

[quote=“Mikeyzzz, post:4, topic:519270”][quote author=robonick8 link=topic=637733.msg4298406#msg4298406 date=1368586037]
I am going to throw something out my window cause this is like impossible and makes no sense

One day, a person went to a race track. Instead of counting the number of human and cars, he instead counted 74 heads and 196 tires. Yet he knew the number of humans and horses there. How did he do it, and how many humans and cars are there?

My teacher gave us this for extra credit for 80 points lol and I have asked so many people. Any idea? SOMETHING? or do i need a scientist
[/quote]74 humans, as there are 74 heads.

196/4 = 49 therefore 49 cars.

not sure but yeah.[/quote]
14 people rode a bike lol.

Read full topic

item.title: Question made my brain explode
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

A typical vehicle has 4 wheels.
A truck also has 4 wheels.
Unless it’s a dully, in that case it has 6 to 8 wheels.
These are all typical numbers, and do not include spares.
Trailers vary…
They have 3 wheel, 5 wheel, and more.
It depends on the size of the hull. (How many horses you’re expecting to carry etc).
Each trailer would have a spare.
That is a lot of variables you need to look into before you can even begin to do the math about the heads…

Read full topic

item.title: Question made my brain explode
item.dc:creator: @xxx123xxx xxx123xxx
item.description:
@xxx123xxx wrote:

[quote=“Davidi2, post:10, topic:519270”]When did he say ‘on’ the track? He just said ‘at’ the track There would never be any cars ‘on’ the horse race track, and if we’re talking about people parking in other places, what is there to say other people couldn’t have parked other places too?

Edit -
@OP - You will be best to go with Niall’s solution I think, just explaining the possible solutions given the information provided. Unless there is something secret we are all missing, there is no concrete answer to this question.[/quote]
Yup, OP ask your teacher for a rewrite to clear up any misconceptions or just take it as is

That implies that the horse riders didn’t get there by car

item.title: Question made my brain explode
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

[quote=“xxx123xxx, post:7, topic:519270”]assuming that 1 car is owned by 1 human, and that 1 horse has 1 human rider

a car usually has 4 tires so
196/4 = 49 cars = so at least 49 people have cars

and since there are 75 heads including yours ( 49 of which we know are human heads since horseas can’t drive cars as far as I know) that leaves us with 26 heads

since we can only have 1 person to a horse
that leaves us with 13 horses and 13 people

So there are :
13 horses
49 cars
62 humans[/quote]That implies that the horse riders didn’t get there by car

Read full topic

@xxx123xxx wrote:

assuming that 1 car is owned by 1 human, and that 1 horse has 1 human rider

a car usually has 4 tires so
196/4 = 49 cars = so at least 49 people have cars

and since there are 75 heads including yours ( 49 of which we know are human heads since horseas can’t drive cars as far as I know) that leaves us with 26 heads

since we can only have 1 person to a horse
that leaves us with 13 horses and 13 people

So there are :
13 horses
49 cars

item.title: Question made my brain explode
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

I was assuming the horses had two-wheeled cart with a rider. But why are the cars in a horse race?

Each horse/rider pair is two heads and two tires.
Each car is one head and four tires.

He counted the amount of heads and tires, but I assume he counted himself too, so I’m subtracting him from the rest of the problem.

tires = 196
heads = 74 - 1 = 73

(There is as many heads as tires for a horse driver pair, so I find how many cars it needs to be on the track to fulfil that requirement)
heads - x = tires - 4x
3x = tires - (heads - 1)
3x = 196 - 73
x = 41

41 four-wheeled cars with a driver.

You have then left
32 tires and 32 heads.

16 (2 * tires + 2 * heads) = 16 horses with rider in a cart.
People = 74 - 16 = 58

So there is 41 cars and 58 people (Including yourself).

Read full topic

item.title: Question made my brain explode
item.dc:creator: @The_Un-Named The Un-Named
item.description:
@The_Un-Named wrote:

Mikeyzzz, the question states that the person counted the heads, and asks how many people and horses there are, therefore the number of heads given includes horse heads.

The question provides the following information: the amount of wheels and the amount of heads, assuming that a typical car has 4 wheels and that since the number of wheels is divisible by 4, then presumably there are 49 cars. You also have to assume that for every car there is at least 1 person as a driver, so there are at least 49 drivers, that gives a headcount of 25 left.

Deciding what to classify the remaining 25 heads as is a little tricky. The question is extremely vague and you really don’t know what the question is trying to test. You can leave it as simply, there are 49 cars, at least 49 people, and presumably 25 horses. The question however could be testing to see how well you think outside the box, or how well you think inside the box. How many horses are typically raced at a race track? If the local horse racing only accepts 8 starters, you could explain that you think there are 66 people and 8 horses. The question may trick you into thinking that the car has to be a 4 wheel car, there could be any number of 3 wheel cars so long as they add up to multiples of 4, which would reduce the amount of cars for example. How you answer the question depends on how you interpret what it is trying to test for.

Read full topic

item.title: Question made my brain explode
item.dc:creator: @heroisgay heroisgay
item.description:
@heroisgay wrote:

So there are both horses and cars at the race track? Given the information we can assume there are 49 cars, are the cars in the race and is there only 1 human to a car? 1 human to a horse and we aren’t counting people not in the race? That leaves 25 heads of humans/horses(if they are included) after the cars. Honestly though this seems like a ‘think outside the box’ problem, because imo there is a lack of information on the specifics here.

Read full topic
